TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Fine, smectitic Typic Glossocryalfs

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Nokhu loam - forest.  (Colors are for dry soil unless otherwise noted.)
01--3 to 1 inches; undecomposed organic material principally needles, bark, twigs, and leaves.
02--1 to 0 inches; partially decomposed organic material like that of the horizon above.
A1--0 to 1 inches; dark gray (10YR 4/1) loam, black (10YR 2/1) moist; strong medium crumb structure; soft, very friable, slightly sticky, slightly plastic; neutral (pH 6.6); abrupt smooth boundary.  (0 to 3 inches thick)
A2--1 to 6 inches; light brownish gray (10YR 6/2) loam, grayish brown (10YR 5/2) moist; weak thin platy structure that parts to moderate fine and very fine granules; soft, very friable, slightly sticky, slightly plastic; neutral (ph 6.6); clear smooth boundary.  (4 to 12 inches thick)
A&B--6 to 14 inches; mixed light brownish gray (10YR 6/2) and brown (10YR 5/3) loam, grayish brown (10YR 5/2) and dark brown (10YR 4/3) moist; weak fine subangular blocky structure that parts to moderate fine granules; slightly hard, very friable, slightly sticky, slightly plastic; the more clayey peds are very hard; thin wax-like patches on some faces of peds and wax-like coatings and fillings in root channels in the more clayey peds; this horizon consists of seams and nodules of clayey material like that of the underlying horizon embedded in a light color matrix like that of the overlying horizon; neutral (pH 6.6); gradual wavy boundary.  (4 to 19 inches thick)
B2t--14 to 32 inches; brown (10YR 5/3) heavy clay loam, dark brown (10YR 4/3) moist; strong medium angular and subangular blocky structure; slightly hard, very friable, very sticky, very plastic; peds are extremely hard, very firm; continuous wax-like coatings on faces of peds in root channels and in pores; wax-like rims around the entrance to some pores; 5 percent gravel; neutral (pH 6.6); gradual wavy boundary.  (7 to 45 inches thick)
B3--32 to 36 inches; brown (10YR 5/3) light clay loam, dark brown (10YR 4/3) moist; moderate medium and coarse subangular blocky structure; slightly hard, very friable, slightly sticky; slightly plastic; peds are extremely hard, firm; thin wax-like patches on some faces of peds and in some root channels and pores; 5 percent gravel; mildly alkaline (pH 7.8); clear wavy boundary.  (2 to 10 inches thick)
Cca--36 to 50 inches; pale brown (10YR 6/3) light clay loam, yellowish brown (10YR 5/4) moist; massive; very hard, firm, slightly sticky, slightly plastic; 5 percent gravel; visible secondary calcium carbonate occurring as concretions and in thin seams and streaks; calcareous moderately alkaline (pH 8.2)

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION:  Jackson County, Colorado; approximately 1,000 feet west and 100 feet south of NE corner Sec. 23, T. 7 N., R. 78 W.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:  Mean annual soil temperature is about 40 degrees F., and mean summer soil temperature is about 51 degrees F.  Depth to uniformly calcareous material ranges from 17 to 55 inches.  Base saturation ranges from 60 to 100 percent in all subhorizons of the argillic horizon.  Depth to continuous horizons of visible secondary calcium carbonate accumulation ranges from 17 to 55 inches.  Depth to the top of the argillic horizon is less than 24 inches and depth to base of the argillic horizon ranges from 17 to 55 inches.  Rock fragments range from 0 to 35 percent in a major part of the solum and C and are mainly 0 to 10 inches in diameter.
The A1 horizon if present, has hue of 5Y through 7.5YR, value of 4 or 5 dry, 2 or 3 moist, and chroma of 1 through 3.  It ranges from slightly acid to mildly alkaline.
The A2 horizon has hue of 5Y through 7.5YR, value of 5 through 8 dry, 4 through 7 moist, and chroma of 1 through 4.  It ranges from slightly acid to mildly alkaline.
The B2t horizon has hue of 5Y through 7.5YR, value of 5 through dry, 4 through 6 moist, and chroma of 1 through 6.  It is typically heavy clay loam or clay but averages 35 to 60 percent clay, 5 to 45 percent silt, an 15 to 55 percent sand with more than 15 percent fine or coarser sand.   This horizon ranges from slightly acid to mildly alkaline.
The C horizon has hue of 5Y through 7.5YR.  This horizon ranges from moderately to strongly alkaline and has 4 to 14 percent calcium carbonate equivalent.  It is loam, clay loam or sandy clay loam with clay ranging from 18 to 35 percent.

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES:  These are the Asperson, Azarman, Bead, Chubbs, Contide, Cowdrey, Dell, Foxton, Gateway, Hatch, Lail, McVickers, Mikesell, Muggins, Wetterhorn, and Wickenson series.  Asperson, Gateway, and Hatch soils have a paralithic contact at depths of less than 40 inches.  Azarman and Cowdrey soils lack consistent horizons of visible secondary calcium carbonate accumulation above a depth of 40 inches and are noncalcareous throughout.  Bead, Lail, and Muggins soils have hue of 5YR or redder.  Chubbs, Foxton, McVickers, Wetterhorn, and Wickenson soils have a lithic contact at depths of less than 40 inches.  Contide soils have sola thicker than 55 inches and have very think A2 and A&B horizons with the top of the argillic horizon occurring at depths greater than 24 inches.  Dell soils lack consistent visible accumulation of secondary calcium carbonate above a depth of 40 inches.  Mikesell soils have sola 40 to 65 inches thick that extend to bedrock and are noncalcareous throughout.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:  Nokhu soils are on gently to steeply sloping alluvial fans, mountainsides, and valley filling side slopes.  Slopes typically range from about 2 to 50 percent.  These soils formed in thick, calcareous, medium to moderately fine textured materials derived from sedimentary, metamorphic, and igneous rocks.  At the type location the mean annual precipitation is about 25 inches with peak periods of precipitation in the spring and summer.  Mean annual temperature is 36 degrees F.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS:  These are the Cowdrey and Gothic soils.  Cowdrey soils are noncalcareous throughout.  Gothic soils have more than 35 percent clay to a depth of more than 55 inches, are noncalcareous throughout, and have a mollic epipedon.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:  Well-drained; medium to rapid runoff; slow permeability.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION:  These soils are used as native pastureland, for recreation, and for timber production.  Native vegetation is lodgepole pine, aspen, spruce, fir, and an understory of grasses and shrubs.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT: Mountain area of Colorado.  The series is of moderate extent.

REGIONAL OFFICE.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
REGIONAL OFFICE.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE: Bozeman, Montana

REMARKS.content:
REMARKS:  Last updated by the state 11/73.
